qas.question: The plans called for how many bits as a feature?
Who was the Nintendo president at the time?
When was the test model constructed?
Early Famicom games were written on what computer system?
The first plans called for how many bits as a feature?
Who was the Nintendo vice president at the time?
When was the test model destroyed?
Early Famicom games weren't written on what computer system?

context: Following a series of arcade game successes in the early 1980s, Nintendo made plans to create a cartridge-based console called the Famicom. <a0_0><b5_0>Masayuki Uemura<b5_0/><a0_0/> designed the system. Original plans called for an advanced <a1_0><b6_0>16<a1_0/>-bit<b6_0/> system which would function as a full-fledged computer with a keyboard and floppy disk drive, but Nintendo president <a2_0><b7_0>Hiroshi Yamauchi<b7_0/><a2_0/> rejected this and instead decided to go for a cheaper, more conventional cartridge-based game console as he felt that features such as keyboards and disks were intimidating to non-technophiles. A test model was constructed in <a3_0><b8_0>October 1982<b8_0/><a3_0/> to verify the functionality of the hardware, after which work began on programming tools. Because 65xx CPUs had not been manufactured or sold in Japan up to that time, no cross-development software was available and it had to be produced from scratch. Early Famicom games were written on a system that ran on an <a4_0><b9_0>NEC PC-8001<b9_0/><a4_0/> computer and LEDs on a grid were used with a digitizer to design graphics as no software design tools for this purpose existed at that time.[citation needed]
